awd_titl_txt: DMREF/GOALI/Collaborative Research: High-Throughput Simulations and Experiments to Develop Metallic Glasses
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Description: The increasing demand for higher performing materials across many fields requires the development of ever more complex materials. In this project a novel materials discovery methodology will be developed based on advances in combinatorial computational thermodynamics and experimental techniques. Bulk metallic glasses will be taken as example materials because of their technological potential - they can be considered high-strength metals that can be formed like plastics - and their suitability for the development of a general methodology. Many alloys - on the order of thousands - will be synthesized and characterized simultaneously. The ability of these alloys to be deformed, a property that correlates with the glass forming ability, will be measured experimentally. The crystalline phases competing with the glassy phase will also be characterized. These crystalline phases will be compared with atomic modeling results considering the energy of many possible crystalline phases. Since direct modeling of the glass forming ability is not possible from first principles, correlations will be established between the experimental glass forming ability and the competing crystalline phases from atomic modeling. The development of such a methodology and correlation through this research will accelerate the pace of discovery and deployment of advanced materials. Specifically for bulk metallic glasses, the potential development of technologically relevant alloys, particularly those that are based on Cu or Al can be expected to have a lasting impact on society.

Technical Description: This objective will be realized through an integrated approach of combinatorial ab-initio simulations, combinatorial synthesis of sputtered composition spreads, and high-throughput characterization methods. To massively parallel synthesize complex alloy systems comprising ~1,000 alloys, this research uses combinatorial magnetron sputtering. Compositional libraries will be characterized using specific high-throughput methods for measuring liquidus temperature, formability, thermal, and structural properties. Within such an approach a vast amount of experimental and computational data will be generated, which will be data-mined to identify correlations. Rather than trying to directly simulate glass formation, the strategy will be to integrate experiments and computations to understand which structural and energetic aspects of the liquid and competing crystalline state best correlate with glass forming ability. Identifying correlations is a key aspect of the research and these correlations will be used to search for new glass forming compositions through combined computational and experimental means.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of the project is to develop bulk metallic glasses (BMGs) based on high-throughput computing, materials synthesis, and characterization. This goal includes developing a fundamental understanding of the physical mechanisms underlying glass formation in metallic alloy systems, and then using this newly developed understanding to develop predictive models to accelerate the design of new metallic glass materials, and finally to actually produce and test new materials for commercial and industrial applications. The metallic glass materials that will be developed as a result of this project will combine the strength and elasticity of metals with the workability and processability of polymers. The prospect of obtaining inexpensive materials that combine such properties is very promising and explains the large industrial and academic interest in this class of materials.

This project is organized as a collaboration between three different research groups. The Center for Materials Genomics at Duke University led by Prof. Stefano Curtarolo is in charge of the computational materials science and data-mining aspects; the group at Yale University led by Prof. Jan Schroers is responsible for combinatorial synthesis; and the group in Harvard University led by Prof. Joost Vlassak is involved in the characterization of the composition spreads.

The Duke group uses the AFLOW [1, 2] database of binary structures to generate models and descriptors to understand and predict the glass-forming ability (GFA) of metal alloy systems. The AFLOW database consists of hundreds of thousands of unique entries containing structural and thermodynamic data on different materials. Given the agnostic way in which the database is built, it can be used to predict properties and new materials. Therefore, the Duke group is committed to combining computational theory with a physical Ansatz to develop new descriptors that can be computed in a high-throughput way for hundreds of different metallic alloy systems. Achieving success in this goal would open up the possibility of virtually cost-free, rapid, high-throughput screening of large numbers of materials to identify potential glass-formers, significantly accelerating and reducing the cost of the design of new bulk metallic glasses. This search is performed in close cooperation with the groups at Yale and Harvard. The Yale group focuses on combinatorial synthesis of thin-film libraries of BMG forming systems. These libraries, also called composition spreads, are characterized using scanning x-ray diffraction to determine the competing crystalline phases and their structure, and automated energy dispersive analysis to determine the compositions of these phases. The Harvard group focuses on nanocalorimetry characterization of the composition spreads to determine glass-forming ability (GFA) related thermophysical properties of metallic glasses, such as temperatures and enthalpies of glass transition, crystallization, and melting.

Additional specific goals for this period include the extension of the AFLOW GFA descriptor to predict glass formation in ternary and higher-order alloy systems, and the construction of machine-learning models trained on the combination of experimental and AFLOW-computed data for identifying new glass forming compositions. The first stage is the development of a machine-learning model to automate the classification of x-ray diffraction spectra. This model streamlines the characterization of combinational libraries by automatically identifying amorphous metallic alloys. This will be followed by the construction of an additional model to predict the glass forming ability of a material. The goal is that the model will make predictions based solely on composition alone, which will accelerate materials discovery by providing a method to target potential glass formers and eliminate the trial and error associated with synthesis.

Work on generalizing the GFA descriptor includes incorporating the competition between linear combinations of phases with different compositions, an effect that becomes more important as the number of elemental components increases. Calculations of ternary structures are currently ongoing to add additional data to the AFLOW database, and preliminary investigations on using machine-learning models to accelerate the generation of thermodynamic density of states data to assist in the identification of relevant crystalline phases are also underway.
